titleStmt.title: Walt Whitman's Reading: A Bibliographical Handlist
a machine readable transcription

availability.p: The text encoding and content of this bibliography were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of these materials should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

bibl.author: Emory Holloway
bibl.title: The Uncollected Poetry and Prose of Walt Whitman

bibl.author: C. Carroll Hollis
bibl.title: Whitman and William Swinton: A Collaborative Friendship
American Literature

bibl.note: Whitman's copy
Whitman's notes
Whitman's marginalia

div1.head: Whitman's Reading: A Bibliographical Handlist
div1.p: Walt Whitman was an extensive reader, and like many of us, he kept notes—in the margins, on scraps of paper, and in notebooks—about his reading. This section of the Archive offers a growing list of books and documents known to have been read or encountered by America's most famous poet. From classical rhetoric to the poetry of Tennyson, from Persian mysticism to nineteenth-century phrenological journals, the influences on Whitman's work were historically deep and culturally diverse.

bibl.author: Epictetus
bibl.title: The Encheiridion
bibl.note: Several reactions over at least four readings. Extensive markings, with narrative of his readings in endpapers. One of WW's favorites.
Also mentioned in With Walt Whitman in Camden.

bibl.title: English Writers
bibl.note: New York City
Volume now held in Library of Congress
"Here was Milton—the best of Milton, I think—of the two Paradises."
This volume contains a number of other English authors, with WW's marginal notations on them.

bibl.author: Bell, George Joseph
bibl.title: Mrs. Siddons as Lady Macbeth: From Contemporary Notes by George Joseph Bell
The Nineteenth Century: A Monthly Review
bibl.note: Underlines and manicules

bibl.title: The Vanity and the Glory of Literature
The Edinburgh Review, American Edition
bibl.note: Includes two pasteons, entitled, "The Muses" and "Socratic Philosophy."
"My own opinion is that myriads of superior works have been lost—superior to existing works in every department, except law, physics, and the exact sciences."

bibl.author: Dickens, Charles
bibl.title: Dombey and Son
bibl.note: Camden, NJ

Whitman claims this to be his favorite Dickens novel. He refers to it in several places in With Walt Whitman in Camden, see for example 6:149: "Dickens, with his inexpressibly fine touch, pictures the soul—its departure—its floating off in the mist—oh! beautiful! A trick, perhaps, yet how fine!"
See also for example Traubel, WWWC 5:21-22; and 4:235.

bibl.author: Thompson, Benjamin F.
bibl.title: The History of Long Island
bibl.note: Copy held in the Library of Congress, F127.L8 T4 Feinberg Whitman Collection. Further marginalia can be found at loc.03515. Whitman copies notes about Long Island in the margins.

bibl.author: Khayyam, Omar
bibl.title: Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam, the Astronomer-Poet of Persia
bibl.note: Mainly brackets.

bibl.author: Salt, Henry Stevens
bibl.title: The Poet Laureate as Philosopher and Peer
To-Day; The Monthly Magazine of Scientific Socialism
bibl.note: The "Sun-Maiden," by Ernest Radford, appears after the end of this article.

bibl.title: Shakspere as a Man
bibl.note: Clipping from an unidentified newspaper juxtaposed with other clippings and notes on Shakespeare.
"See Emerson's Shakespeare."

bibl.title: The True Character of Goethe
bibl.note: This clipping, which Whitman attached to his notes on Goethe, includes a substantial quote from "Perthes the Publisher, and Literary Germany," published in the February 1857 issue of Titan.

bibl.title: Chips from our Library; a Chance Medley of Fact, Sentiment, and Anecdote
Harper's Weekly. Journal of Civilization.
bibl.note: From this miscellany, Whitman clipped a segment on the "statuesque" descriptions of William Cowper.
Responding to a commentary on William Cowper's "statuesque description," Whitman remarks that Cowper is an "ennuyed poet."
Whitman appends this clipping on William Cowper's poetry to a commentary on British poets.

bibl.author: Carlyle, Thomas
bibl.title: On the Nibelungenlied
bibl.note: Whitman states he is indebted to Carlyle's essay in his notes on the German text.

bibl.author: Gostwick, Joseph
bibl.title: German Literature
bibl.note: According to Edward Grier, Whitman paraphrases Joseph Gostwick's literal translation of the Nibelungenlied from this source. He speculates that "this was written in 1858 or slightly later."

bibl.author: Rousseau, Jean-Jacques
bibl.title: The Confessions of Jean-Jacques Rousseau
bibl.note: Whitman calls the Confessions a "frivolous, chattering, repulsive, book, that still has a great lesson in its pages, and whose revelations one keeps reading somehow to the end."
Whitman references William Swinton's 1856 translation of Rousseau's Confessions twice in his biographical notes on Rousseau.

bibl.author: Thornbury, George Walter
bibl.title: Shakespeare's Stage
bibl.note: Newspaper clipping of a selection from G. W. Thornbury's Shakspeare's England (London, 1856)
This clipping accompanies Whitman's clippings and intensive notes on Shakespeare.

bibl.author: Kavanagh, Julia
bibl.title: The Deaths of Rousseau and Voltaire
bibl.note: This clipping is a reprint of an excerpt from Volume 2 of Julia Kavanaugh's Woman in France During the Eighteenth Century, first published in 1850.
This clipping is included with Whitman's notes on Rousseau and The Confessions of Jean Jacques Rousseau.

bibl.author: Knight, Charles
bibl.title: Half-Hours with the Best Authors
bibl.note: Knight's book includes biographical sketches and textual selections from a wide range of authors.

Whitman disassembled this book of biographical sketches and textual selections and included them in a variety of notebooks. Selections include Jeremy Taylor, Tobias Smollett, Blaise Pascal, and Benjamin Franklin (duk.00170); Comte Du Buffon (duk.00176).
Segments of Whitman's copy are clipped to notes on a variety of authors

bibl.author: Goethe, Johann Wolfgang von
bibl.title: The Complete Works of Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe
bibl.note: "He is the most profound reviewer of life known. To him life, things, the mind, death, are all studies, dissections, exhibitions. These he enters upon with unequalled [sic] coolness and depth of penetration."

Whitman refers to Goethe's Complete Works (first published in 1827) in notes on Goethe dated January 1856, February 18, 1856, and February 22, 1856. Whitman refers to several works in Goethe's oeuvre, but his January entry implies that he hasn't read all of his texts: "Had I not better read more of Goethe before giving an opinion?"

bibl.author: Racine, Jean
bibl.title: Athalie
bibl.note: "I fancy the classical tragedies of Corneille, Racine, Voltaire, &c. must illustrate the vital difference between a native and normal growth (as the Greek tragedies themselves,) and all that comes from the mere study of that growth."
Whitman remarks that he saw "Athalie" at the Academy of Music in November of 1855.
Whitman mentions attending this performance in his notes on tragedy

bibl.author: Alfieri, Vittorio
bibl.title: Myrrha
bibl.note: "lurid passions—with long-winded dialogues between Myrrha and daughter mother about nothing."
Whitman mentions this performance within his notes on tragedy

bibl.author: Ossian
bibl.title: The Poems of Ossian
bibl.note: Whitman references MacPherson's "restoration" of Ossian and states that he is reading Ossian "this morning" (undated).

bibl.author: Rousseau, Jean-Jacques
bibl.title: The Social Contract
bibl.note: Whitman extensively paraphrased and commented on sections of Rousseau's The Social Contract.
Trent Collection of Walt Whitman Manuscripts, Duke University Rare Book, Manuscript, and Special Collections Library
"Some of the most important provisions of the specific laws of the Public Lands of the United States are taken word for word, and idea for idea, from Rousseau's 'Contract.'"

C. Carroll Hollis identifies William Swinton as the source of Whitman's translation and speculates that Swinton read Social Contract to Whitman in a "rough and free translation" while Whitman took notes in 1856.
Page 431. Hollis documents Swinton and Whitman's readings of Rousseau

bibl.title: Voices From the Press; A Collection of Sketches, Essays, and Poems, by Practical Printers
bibl.note: Whitman pasted a note on The Nibelungen onto the front boards of this book.

bibl.author: Wiffen, James Holmes
bibl.title: Life of Torquato Tasso
bibl.note: Floyd Stovall argues that Whitman's notes on Tasso correspond "exactly" with this edition of Wiffen's work.

bibl.title: The New Jerusalem
bibl.note: Whitman's copy of this essay on Emanuel Swedenborg is pasted in a notebook.
Essay was first published in Household Words 13.6 (1856), ed. Charles Dickens (136-141).

bibl.title: Shakespeare versus Sand
American Whig Review
bibl.note: Essay is pasted into notebook.

bibl.author: Mandeville, Henry
bibl.title: Fourth Reader: For common schools and Academies
bibl.note: Whitman cut out a page of the "Poems of Ossian" included in this text and pasted it into a notebook.

bibl.title: Religious Beliefs
bibl.note: Whitman includes this clipping from periodical article on the comparative popularity of world religions.
Whitman's clipping

bibl.title: Life-Force, Its Philosophy
Life Illustrated
bibl.note: This essay accompanies Whitman's notes on insanity.

bibl.author: Bunsen, C.K.J
bibl.title: Outlines of the Philosophy of Universal History, Applied to Language and Religion
bibl.date: During or after 1854, when the book was translated into English

bibl.title: The Muses
bibl.note: Paste-on included with "The Vanity and Glory of Literature" and "Socratic Philosophy."

bibl.title: Socratic Philosophy
bibl.note: Paste-on from a periodical included with "The Muses" and "The Vanity and Glory of Literature."

bibl.title: A Poet on Politics
bibl.note: Clipping of an article about Whitman's views about the 1884 presidential election.
Whitman included this clipping with "Specimen Days" notes about the presidential election of 1884. He claims that this article appeared in The Philadelphia Press on October 30, 1884.

bibl.title: How America was Peopled
bibl.note: Clipping from a newspaper or periodical.
This is a brief clipping on a scholar's lectures on migration to the New World. These accompany Whitman's notes on ancient European and Asian populations.

bibl.author: Longfellow, Henry Wadsworth
bibl.title: Longfellow's Poets and Poetry of Europe
The American Review: A Whig Journal
Webfoots
bibl.note: Clipping with attached note, "The Oregonese are called Webfoots."
Whitman notes that this serial clipping was "from a letter Salem, Oregon Oct. 1870" clipping reproduces a letter from Salem, Oregon in October 1870.

bibl.title: Typical American Canoes at the Annual Meet in Peconic Bay
Harper's Weekly
bibl.note: Clipping from Harper's Weekly.
The back side of this clipping contains material from Charles Waldstein's "Modesty."

bibl.author: Waldstein, Charles
bibl.title: Modesty
Harper's Weekly
bibl.note: This material is on the back side of a picture of a canoe that Whitman cut out from Harper's.

bibl.author: Bell, George Joseph
bibl.title: 'Mrs. Siddons as Lady MacBeth.' From Contemporary Notes by George Joseph Bell."
The Nineteenth Century: A Monthly Review
bibl.note: "In my reading, elocution, I must constantly measure every gesture, tone, conception, shade, burst, or radiation, &c. as to its fitness, appropriateness, advantage (or disadvantage) with reference to me, to my personnel [sic] style, physical & emotional individuality & not merely of its abstract authority."

bibl.author: Pardoe, Miss
bibl.title: Louis the Fourteenth, and the Court of France in the Seventeenth Century
bibl.note: According to Whitman, he owned this edition of Pardoe's text from 1855 to 1889.

bibl.author: Thoreau, Henry David
bibl.title: A Week on the Concord and Merrimack Rivers
bibl.note: Whitman disassembled this text and pasted clippings in at least one notebook. The source of Whitman's clippings is available at loc.03446.

bibl.title: Great Britain (From Our Correspondent)
New-York Daily Tribune
bibl.note: Whitman cut and pasted this selection from the Tribune in his notes and titled it "London Letter."
This letter contains speculation about upcoming work by Sydney Dobell (a.k.a. Sydney Yendya).

bibl.author: Euripedes
bibl.title: The Tragedies of Euripedes. Literally Translated or Revised, with Critical and Explanatory Notes, by
Translated by Theodore Alois Buckley
bibl.note: Whitman notes that he had this text in Washington through the Civil War and later in Camden.

bibl.author: Brodhead, Jacob
bibl.title: A Sermon Preached in the Central Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, Brooklyn, on Sabbath Morning, Th

bibl.author: Radford, Ernest
bibl.title: The Sun-Maiden
To-Day; The Monthly Magazine of Scientific Socialism
bibl.note: Appears immediately after the end of Henry Stevens Salt's "The Poet Laureate as Philosopher and Peer" in To-Day.

bibl.author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
bibl.title: Ulysses
bibl.note: Whitman transcribed the final lines of Tennyson's "Ulysses," which was first published in 1842.
Whitman's transcription

bibl.author: Anacreon
bibl.title: Ode XXXIII
Translated by Thomas Moore
bibl.note: Whitman transcribes and revises Thomas Moore's translation of Anacreon's "Ode XXXIII" and entitles it "The Midnight Visitor." Arthur Golden's "The Text of a Whitman Lincoln Lecture Reading: Anacreon's 'The Midnight Visitor'" argues that Whitman likely preceded an 1879 lecture on Lincoln with a reading of this poem.

bibl.author: Ainsworth, Robert; Morell, Thomas
bibl.title: An Abridgement of Ainsworth's Dictionary, English and Latin, for the use of schools
Adapted by by John Carey

bibl.author: Hoffman, C. F.
bibl.title: The Pioneers of New York; an Anniversary Discourse Delivered Before the St. Nicholas Society of Manh
bibl.note: June '57—"This man is now in an Insane Asylum—it is said, a confirmed lunatic."

bibl.author: Lees, H. A.
bibl.title: Historical sketches of the churches of the city of Brooklyn
bibl.note: Kept in slip-case with Charles Fenno Hoffman's "The Pioneers of New-York" (loc.03454).

bibl.author: Symonds, John Addington
bibl.title: Studies of the Greek Poets
bibl.note: "Sent to me by Symonds, must have been 1881. For years 1882-'89 I sip & drink from the two volumes. They and Walter Scott's Border Minstrels are feasts never exhausted."
Whitman's marginalia to Volume 2 of this book is at loc.03459.

bibl.author: Teale, Thomas P.
bibl.title: Report of the Special Committee, of the Common Council, of the City of Brooklyn, of Ferry and Water
bibl.publisher: E.B Spooner, Printer to the City Corporation
bibl.note: A message inscribed on the title page states: "To W. Whitman Esq with the compliments of the writer."

bibl.title: A Defence of the Christian Doctrines of the Society of Friends; Being a Reply to the Charge of Denyi

bibl.author: Bucke, Richard Maurice
bibl.title: Walt Whitman
bibl.note: Portions of several pages have been cut out.

bibl.author: Shelley, Percy Bysshe
bibl.title: The Works of Percy Bysshe Shelley
Edited by Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley

bibl.author: Volney, C.-F.
bibl.title: The Ruins: or, Meditation on the Revolutions of Empires: and the Law of Nature, to which is added Vo
English translation.
bibl.note: "Translation seems to have been either by Joel Barlow, or supervised by him, in Paris, and favored by Volney."

bibl.author: Heine, Heinrich
bibl.title: Pictures of Travel
Fourth revised edition, Translated by Charles Godfrey Leland

bibl.author: Lewes, George Henry
bibl.title: The life and works of Goethe: with sketches of his age and contemporaries, from published and unpubl
bibl.note: Volume 2 of Lewes's work is listed at bmr.00003

bibl.author: Lewes, George Henry
bibl.title: The Life and Works of Goethe: with Sketches of his Age and Contemporaries, from Published and Unpubl
bibl.note: Volume 1 of Lewes's work is listed at bmr.00002

bibl.author: Mazzini, Giuseppe
bibl.title: The Duties of Man
bibl.note: Whitman's copy of this book is inscribed: "To Walt Whitman, from a Friend." At the end of page 107, a marginal note responds to Mazzini's advice about maintaining tranqulity in adversity with "Remember my friend this Truth—for woman."

author.key: Milton, John; Gray, Thomas; Beattie, James; Collins, William

bibl.title: Milton, Young, Gray, Beattie, and Collins: Complete in one Volume
bibl.note: This book contains work by John Milton, Edward Young, Thomas Gray, James Beattie, and William Collins. Whitman notes birth and death dates of authors and marks significant moments in the text's biographical sketch of John Milton.

bibl.author: Whitney, William Dwight
bibl.title: Oriental and Linguistic Studies: the Veda, the Avesta, The Science of Language
bibl.note: On page 47, the following lines are bracketed: "On the other hand, it is possible to attain to such an exalted pitch of wisdom and virtue, that the soul escapes the condemnation of existence, and sinks into the void, or merges its individuality in the universality of the world-spirit."

bibl.author: Symonds, John Addington
bibl.title: Essays Speculative and Suggestive
bibl.note: Volume 2 of Symonds's work is listed at bmr.00011

bibl.author: Symonds, John Addington
bibl.title: Essays Speculative and Suggestive
bibl.note: Volume 1 of Symonds's work is listed at bmr.00010

bibl.author: Tennyson, Alfred Lord
bibl.title: Locksley Hall sixty years after, etc.

bibl.author: Felton, C. C.
bibl.title: Greece, ancient and modern: Lectures Delivered before the Lowell Institute
bibl.note: Volume 2 of this work is listed at bmr.00013

bibl.title: Greece, ancient and modern: Lectures Delivered before the Lowell Institute
bibl.note: Volume 2 of this work is listed at bmr.00012

bibl.title: John Howard Payne, dramatist, poet, actor and author of Home, sweet home! his life and writings

bibl.title: Journal of the Life and Religious Labours of Elias Hicks

bibl.author: Anacreon
bibl.title: The Odes of Anacreon
Translated by Thomas Moore and accompanied by illustrations by Girodet de Roussy
bibl.note: This volume may be the source text for Whitman's annotation of Ode XXXIII, which he titled "The Midnight Visitor" (loc.03442).

Bhagavad-gita, or, A discourse between Krishna and Arjuna on divine matters
